<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>As of March 5, 2004, the aggregate market value of the
 49,724,783 shares of Common Stock held by non-affiliates of the registrant was $1.2 billion, based upon
 the closing price $24.68 on the New York Stock Exchange composite tape on such date. (For this computation,
 the registrant has excluded the market value of all shares of its Common Stock reported as beneficially
 owned by executive officers and directors of the registrant and certain other shareholders; such exclusion
 shall not be deemed to constitute an admission that any such person is an "affiliate" of the registrant.)
 As of March 5, 2003, there were outstanding 50,456,343 shares of Common Stock. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Major Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Flush Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

 meeting to be held in 2003 are incorporated by reference into Parts II and III. </FONT></P>

<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>PART I </B></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Flush Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Item 1. BUSINESS.</B> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>The Company</B> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Taubman
 Centers, Inc. (&#147;we&#148;, &#147;us&#148;, &#147;our&#148;, or &#147;TCO&#148;) was incorporated in Michigan in 1973 and had our initial
 public offering (&#147;IPO&#148;) in 1992. We own a 61% managing general partner&#146;s interest in The Taubman Realty
 Group Limited Partnership (the &#147;Operating Partnership&#148; or &#147;TRG&#148;), through which we conduct all of our
 operations. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are
 engaged in the ownership, development, acquisition, and operation of regional shopping centers and interests
 therein. Our portfolio, as of December 31, 2003, included 21 urban and suburban centers located in nine
 states. One new center is under construction in North Carolina and is scheduled to open September 15,
 2005. The Operating Partnership also owns certain regional retail shopping center development projects
 and more than 99% of The Taubman Company LLC (the &#147;Manager&#148;), which manages the shopping centers and
 provides other services to the Operating Partnership and to us. See the table on page 10 of this report
 for information regarding the centers. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are
 a real estate investment trust, or REIT, under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the &#147;Code&#148;).
 In order to satisfy the provisions of the Code applicable to REITs, we must distribute to our shareholders
 at least 90% of our REIT taxable income and meet certain other requirements. The Operating Partnership&#146;s
 partnership agreement provides that the Operating Partnership will distribute, at a minimum, sufficient
 amounts to its partners such that our pro rata share will enable us to pay shareholder dividends (including
 capital gains dividends that may be required upon the Operating Partnership&#146;s sale of an asset) that
 will satisfy the REIT provisions of the Code. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Recent Developments </B></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
 a discussion of business developments that occurred in 2003, see Item 7, &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and
 Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#148; (MD&amp;A). </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>The Shopping Center Business</B> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There
 are several types of retail shopping centers, varying primarily by size and marketing strategy. Retail
 shopping centers range from neighborhood centers of less than 100,000 square feet of GLA to regional
 and super-regional shopping centers. Retail shopping centers in excess of 400,000 square feet of GLA
 are generally referred to as &#147;regional&#148; shopping centers, while those centers having in excess of 800,000
 square feet of GLA are generally referred to as &#147;super-regional&#148; shopping centers. Nineteen of our centers
 are &#147;super-regional&#148; centers. In this annual report on Form 10-K, the term &#147;regional shopping centers&#148;
 refers to both regional and super-regional shopping centers. The term &#147;GLA&#148; refers to gross retail space,
 including anchors and mall tenant areas, and the term &#147;Mall GLA&#148; refers to gross retail space, excluding
 anchors. The term &#147;anchor&#148; refers to a department store or other large retail store. The term &#147;mall
 tenants&#148; refers to stores (other than anchors) that are typically specialty retailers and lease space
 in shopping centers. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Business of the Company </B></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We,
 as managing general partner of the Operating Partnership, are engaged in the ownership, management,
 leasing, acquisition, development, and expansion of regional shopping centers. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Sub 2 Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The centers:</FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>are strategically located in major metropolitan areas, many in communities that are among the most affluent in the country, including New York City, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Denver, Detroit, Phoenix, Miami, Dallas, Tampa, Orlando, and Washington, D.C.; </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>range in size between 232,000 and 1.6 million square feet of GLA and between 124,000 and 640,000 square feet of Mall GLA. The smallest center has approximately 40 stores, and the largest has over 200 stores. Of the 21 centers, 19 are super-regional shopping centers; </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>have approximately 2,900 stores operated by its mall tenants under approximately 1,200 trade names; </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>have 66 anchors, operating under 17 trade names; </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<H1 align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" color=#0000ff size=2>1 </FONT></H1>

<!-- MARKER PAGE="sheet: 87; page: 87" -->
<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>lease most of Mall GLA to national chains, including subsidiaries or divisions of The Limited (The Limited, Express, Victoria's Secret, and others), Gap (Gap, Gap Kids, Banana Republic, and others), and Foot Locker, Inc. (Foot Locker, Lady Foot Locker, Champs Sports, and others); and </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>are among the most productive (measured by mall tenants&#146; average per square foot sales) in the United States. In 2003, mall tenants had average per square foot sales of $468, which is significantly greater than the average for all regional shopping centers owned by public companies. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
 most important factor affecting the revenues generated by the centers is leasing to mall tenants (primarily
 specialty retailers), which represents approximately 90% of revenues. Anchors account for less than
 10% of revenues because many own their stores and, in general, those that lease their stores do so at
 rates substantially lower than those in effect for mall tenants. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 portfolio is concentrated in highly productive super-regional shopping centers. Of the 21 centers, 20
 had annual rent rolls at December 31, 2003 of over $10 million. We believe that this level of productivity
 is indicative of the centers&#146; strong competitive position and is, in significant part, attributable
 to our business strategy and philosophy. We believe that large shopping centers (including regional
 and especially super-regional shopping centers) are the least susceptible to direct competition because
 (among other reasons) anchors and large specialty retail stores do not find it economically attractive
 to open additional stores in the immediate vicinity of an existing location for fear of competing with
 themselves. In addition to the advantage of size, we believe that the centers&#146; success can be attributed
 in part to their other physical characteristics, such as design, layout, and amenities. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Business Strategy And Philosophy</I> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe
 that the regional shopping center business is not simply a real estate development business, but rather
 an operating business in which a retailing approach to the on-going management and leasing of the centers
 is essential. Thus we: </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>offer a large, diverse selection of retail stores in each center to give customers a broad selection of consumer goods and variety of price ranges. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>endeavor to increase overall mall tenants&#146; sales by leasing space to a constantly changing mix of tenants, thereby increasing achievable rents. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>seek to anticipate trends in the retailing industry and emphasizes ongoing introductions of new retail concepts into our centers. Due in part to this strategy, a number of successful retail trade names have opened their first mall stores in the centers. In addition, we have brought to the centers &#147;new to the market&#148; retailers. We believe that the execution of this leasing strategy has been unique in the industry and is an important element in building and maintaining customer loyalty and increasing mall productivity. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>provide innovative initiatives that utilize technology and the Internet to heighten the shopping experience, build customer loyalty and increase tenant sales. One such initiative is our Taubman Center Website Program, which connects shoppers and retailers through an interactive content-driven website and a robust direct email program. More than 98% of the managed centers&#146; tenants provide content on a weekly basis for the program. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
 centers compete for retail consumer spending through diverse, in-depth presentations of predominantly
 fashion merchandise in an environment intended to facilitate customer shopping. While some centers include
 stores that target high-end, upscale customers, each center is individually merchandised in light of
 the demographics of its potential customers within convenient driving distance. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 leasing strategy involves assembling a diverse mix of mall tenants in each of the centers in order to
 attract customers, thereby generating higher sales by mall tenants. High sales by mall tenants make
 the centers attractive to prospective tenants, thereby increasing the rental rates that prospective
 tenants are willing to pay. We implement an active leasing strategy to increase the centers&#146; productivity
 and to set minimum rents at higher levels. Elements of this strategy include terminating leases of under-performing
 tenants, renegotiating existing leases, and not leasing space to prospective tenants that (though viable
 or attractive in certain ways) would not enhance a center&#146;s retail mix. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<H1 align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" color=#0000ff size=2>2 </FONT></H1>

<!-- MARKER PAGE="sheet: 88; page: 88" -->
<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Potential For Growth</I> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 principal objective is to enhance shareholder value. We seek to maximize the financial results of our
 core assets, while also pursuing a growth strategy that primarily includes an active new center development
 program. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><U>Internal Growth</U> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We expect
 that 90% of our future growth will come from our existing core portfolio and business. Although we&#146;ve
 always had a culture of intensively managing our assets and maximizing the rents from tenants, we&#146;re
 committed to improving the processes that significantly impact the core portfolio in order to drive
 even better performance. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 core business strategy is to maintain a portfolio of properties that deliver above-market profitable
 growth by providing targeted retailers with the best opportunity to do business in each market and targeted
 shoppers with the best local shopping experience for their needs. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are
 working on three endeavors that we believe will lead to achievement of our key mission to &#147;deliver above
 market profitable growth&#148;. Our first endeavor is to become an even more customer centric company than
 we are today, which will enable us to make better decisions driven by a fact-based understanding of
 what retailers and shoppers want. Our second endeavor is to become more operationally excellent, which
 will enable us to achieve competitive cost efficiencies, greater discipline, and more timely processes
 and decision making. This is especially important as our competitors search for economies of scale in
 increasingly larger operations. Our third endeavor is to achieve profitable growth, which we&#146;ve defined
 as maintaining the highest tenant sales and sales growth in the industry, and accelerating core operations
 growth over time. We believe further integrating these basic strategic themes throughout the organization
 will serve to coordinate and prioritize all of our efforts to achieve our strategy. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We&#146;ve
 identified the key drivers to achieve our core business strategy. These drivers fall into four categories:
 people drivers, organizational drivers, customer drivers and financial drivers. These drivers served
 as a basis for the companywide initiatives we worked on in 2003 and that we believe will establish a
 strong foundation for improved core performance. We made progress on our initiatives, including the
 implementation of a new lease process software package in 2003, which will help reduce the time between
 a tenant leaving a space and a new tenant paying rent in that space. In addition, in a year which we&#146;ve
 experienced significant early tenant terminations, we&#146;ve worked to maximize income by increasing the
 number of temporary tenants. Also, we&#146;ve made improvements to our tenant grading system to ensure that
 the system is a strong predictor of a new tenant&#146;s ability to pay contract rent for its entire term
 and to establish risk parameters for each asset to guide our leasing team. We&#146;re continuing to work
 on these and other initiatives to improve core performance. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We strongly
 believe that focusing management attention on these initiatives will improve our performance on these
 drivers and by establishing specific benchmarks and goals for these drivers, which we can measure year
 after year, we will have set the stage for future strong core operations growth. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Sub 2 Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT size=2><U>Development of New Centers</U></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are
 pursuing an active program of regional shopping center development. We believe that we have the expertise
 to develop economically attractive regional shopping centers through intensive analysis of local retail
 opportunities. We believe that the development of new centers is an important use of our capital and
 an area in which we excel. At any time, we have numerous potential development projects in various stages.
 </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
 Mall at Millenia, a 1.1 million square foot center in which the Operating Partnership has a 50% interest,
 opened in October 2002 in Orlando, Florida. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stony
 Point Fashion Park, a 665,000 square foot wholly-owned center, opened September 18, 2003 in Richmond,
 Virginia. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Northlake
 Mall, a 1.1 million square foot wholly-owned center in Charlotte, North Carolina is currently under
 construction and is scheduled to open September 15, 2005. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<H1 align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" color=#0000ff size=2>3 </FONT></H1>

<!-- MARKER PAGE="sheet: 89; page: 89" -->
<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 approximately $34.2 million balance of development pre-construction costs as of December 31, 2003 consists
 of costs relating to our Oyster Bay project in Syosset, New York. Refer to Management&#146;s Discussion and
 Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations-Planned Capital Spending regarding the status
 of this project. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 policies with respect to development activities are designed to reduce the risks associated with development.
 We generally do not intend to acquire land early in the development process. Instead, we generally acquire
 options on land or form partnerships with landholders holding potentially attractive development sites.
 We typically exercise the options only once we are prepared to begin construction. The pre-construction
 phase for a regional center typically extends over several years and the time to obtain anchor commitments,
 zoning and regulatory approvals, and public financing arrangements can vary significantly from project
 to project. In addition, we do not intend to begin construction until a sufficient number of anchor
 stores have agreed to operate in the shopping center, such that we are confident that the projected
 sales and rents from Mall GLA are sufficient to earn a return on invested capital in excess of our cost
 of capital. Having historically followed these principles, our experience indicates that, on average,
 less than 10% of the costs of the development of a regional shopping center will be incurred prior to
 the construction period. However, no assurance can be given that we will continue to be able to so limit
 pre-construction costs. Unexpected costs due to extended zoning and regulatory processes may cause our
 investment in a project to exceed this historic experience. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While
 we will continue to evaluate development projects using criteria, including financial criteria for rates
 of return, similar to those employed in the past, no assurances can be given that the adherence to these
 policies will produce comparable results in the future. In addition, the costs of shopping center development
 opportunities that are explored but ultimately abandoned will, to some extent, diminish the overall
 return on development projects (see Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and
 Results of Operations &#151; Liquidity and Capital Resources &#151; Capital Spending for further discussion of
 our development activities). </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><U>Strategic Acquisitions</U> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 objective is to acquire existing centers only when they are compatible with the quality of our portfolio
 (or can be redeveloped to that level) and that satisfy our strategic plans and pricing requirements.
 During 2003 we acquired: </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>a 25% interest in Waterside Shops at Pelican Bay in Naples, Florida. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

</TABLE>

</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><U>Expansions of the Centers</U> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Another
 potential element of growth is the strategic expansion of existing properties to update and enhance
 their market positions, by replacing or adding new anchor stores or increasing mall tenant space. Most
 of the centers have been designed to accommodate expansions. Expansion projects can be as significant
 as new shopping center construction in terms of scope and cost, requiring governmental and existing
 anchor store approvals, design and engineering activities, including rerouting utilities, providing
 additional parking areas or decking, acquiring additional land, and relocating anchors and mall tenants
 (all of which must take place with a minimum of disruption to existing tenants and customers). </FONT>
</P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para (List) Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

</TABLE>


<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para (List) Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Rental Rates </I></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As leases
 have expired in the centers, we have generally been able to rent the available space, either to the
 existing tenant or a new tenant, at rental rates that are higher than those of the expired leases. In
 a period of increasing sales, rents on new leases will tend to rise as tenants&#146; expectations of future
 growth become more optimistic. In periods of slower growth or declining sales, rents on new leases will
 grow more slowly or will decline for the opposite reason. However, center revenues nevertheless increase
 as older leases roll over or are terminated early and replaced with new leases negotiated at current
 rental rates that are usually higher than the average rates for existing leases. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<H1 align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" color=#0000ff size=2>5 </FONT></H1>

<!-- MARKER PAGE="sheet: 91; page: 91" -->
<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>(1) </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>A higher percentage of space at value centers (Arizona Mills, Dolphin Mall, and Great Lakes Crossing) is typically rented to major and mall tenants at lower rents than the portfolio average. Excluding value centers, the annualized base rent under expiring leases is greater by a range of $3.66 to $13.82 or an average of $8.17 for the periods presented within this table. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>


<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para (List) Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>(2) </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>Excludes leases that expire in 2004 for which renewal leases or leases with replacement tenants have been executed as of December 31, 2003. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>


<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para (List) Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>(3) </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>Table excludes Waterside Shops at Pelican Bay. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe
 that the information in the table is not necessarily indicative of what will occur in the future because
 of several factors, but principally because of early lease terminations at the centers. For example,
 the average remaining term of the leases that were terminated during the period 1997 to 2003 was approximately
 two years. The average term of leases signed during 2003 and 2002 was approximately seven years. </FONT>
</P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition,
 mall tenants at the centers may seek the protection of the bankruptcy laws, which could result in the
 termination of such tenants&#146; leases and thus cause a reduction in cash flow. In 2003, approximately
 2.3% of leases were so affected compared to 1.7% in 2002. This statistic has ranged from 1.2% to 4.5%
 since we went public in 1992. Since 1991, the annual provision for losses on accounts receivable has
 been less than 2% of annual revenues. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Occupancy </I></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

 comparable centers, leased space, ending occupancy, and average occupancy were 90.0%, 88.1%, and 87.8%,
 respectively, in 2003, and 93.3%, 90.3%, and 88.2%, respectively, in 2002. Mall tenant average occupancy,
 ending occupancy, and leased space rates of all centers are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Major Tenants</I> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No single
 retail company represents 10% or more of our revenues. The combined operations of The Limited, Inc.
 accounted for approximately 5.2% of Mall GLA as of December 31, 2003 and 5.3% of 2003 minimum rent.
 No other single retail company accounted for more than 3% of Mall GLA or 4% of 2003 minimum rent. The
 following table shows the ten largest tenants and their square footage as of December 31, 2003: </FONT>
</P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>General Risks of the Company</B> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Economic Performance and Value of Shopping Centers
 Dependent on Many Factors</I> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
 economic performance and value of our shopping centers are dependent on various factors. Additionally,
 these same factors will influence our decision whether to go forward on the development of new centers
 and may affect the ultimate economic performance and value of projects under construction (see other
 risks associated with the development of new centers under &#147;Business of the Company &#151; Development of
 New Centers&#148;). Such factors include: </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>changes in the national, regional, and/or local economic and geopolitical climates, </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>competition from other shopping centers, discount stores, outlet malls, discount shopping clubs, direct mail, and the internet in attracting customers and tenants, </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>increases in operating costs, </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>the public perception of the safety of customers at the shopping centers, </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>environmental or legal liabilities, </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>availability and cost of financing, and </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>uninsured losses, whether because of unavailability of coverage or in excess of policy specifications and insured limits, including those resulting from wars, acts of terrorism, riots or civil disturbances, or losses from earthquakes or floods. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Flush Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>In addition, the value of shopping centers may be adversely
 affected by: </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>changes in government regulations, and </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>changes in real estate zoning and tax laws. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Adverse
 changes in the economic performance and value of shopping centers would adversely affect our income
 and cash available to pay dividends. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<H1 align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" color=#0000ff size=2>7 </FONT></H1>

<!-- MARKER PAGE="sheet: 93; page: 93" -->
<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Third Party Interests in the Centers</I> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Some
 of the shopping centers are partially owned by non-affiliated partners through joint venture arrangements.
 As a result, we do not control all decisions regarding those shopping centers and may be required to
 take actions that are in the interest of the joint venture partners but not our best interests. </FONT>
</P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Bankruptcy of Mall Tenants or Joint Venture Partners
 </I></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We could
 be adversely affected by the bankruptcy of third parties. The bankruptcy of a mall tenant could result
 in the termination of its lease which would lower the amount of cash generated by that mall. In addition,
 if a department store operating an anchor at one of our shopping centers were to go into bankruptcy
 and cease operating, its closing may lead to reduced customer traffic and lower mall tenant sales which
 would, in turn, affect the amount of rent our tenants pay us. The profitability of shopping centers
 held in a joint venture could also be adversely affected by the bankruptcy of one of the joint venture
 partners if, because of certain provisions of the bankruptcy laws, we were unable to make important
 decisions in a timely fashion or became subject to additional liabilities. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Investments in and Loans to Third Parties </I></FONT>
</P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We occasionally
 extend credit to third parties in connection with the sale of land or other transactions. We have occasionally
 made investments in marketable and other equity securities. We are exposed to risk in the event the
 values of our investments and/or our loans decrease due to overall market conditions, business failure,
 and/or other nonperformance by the investees or counterparties. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Third Party Contracts</I> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We provide
 property management, leasing, development, and other administrative services to centers owned by General
 Motors pension trusts, other third parties and to certain Taubman affiliates. The contracts under which
 these services are provided may be canceled or not renewed or may be renegotiated on terms less favorable
 to us. Certain overhead costs allocated to these contracts would not be eliminated if the contracts
 were to be canceled or not renewed. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Flush Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Inability to Maintain Status as a REIT</I> </FONT>
</P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>We may not be able to maintain our status as a real estate investment trust, or REIT, for Federal income tax purposes with the result that the income distributed to shareholders will not be deductible in computing taxable income and instead would be subject to tax at regular corporate rates. Although we believe we are organized and operate in a manner to maintain our REIT qualification, many of the REIT requirements of the Internal Revenue Code are very complex and have limited judicial or administrative interpretations. Changes in tax laws or regulations or new administrative interpretations and court decisions may also affect our ability to maintain REIT status in the future. If we fail to qualify as a REIT, our income may also be subject to the alternative minimum tax. If we do not maintain our REIT status in any year, we may be unable to elect to be treated as a REIT for the next four taxable years. In addition, if we fail to meet
the Internal Revenue Code&#146;s requirement that we distribute to shareholders at least 90% of our otherwise taxable income, less capital gain income, we will be subject to a nondeductible 4% excise tax. The Internal Revenue Code does provide that an additional dividend payment may be declared and paid in the following taxable year so that we will be deemed to have distributed at least 90% of our taxable income to shareholders and thereby maintain our REIT status. The 4% excise tax is due and payable on the additional dividend payment made in the succeeding tax year in order to meet the 90% distribution requirement. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Large Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>
<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>o </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>Although we currently intend to maintain our status as a REIT, future economic, market, legal, tax, or other considerations may cause us to determine that it would be in our and our shareholders&#146; best interests to revoke our REIT election. As noted above, if we revoke our REIT election, we will not be able to elect REIT status for the next four taxable years. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<BR>
<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<H1 align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" color=#0000ff size=2>8 </FONT></H1>

<!-- MARKER PAGE="sheet: 94; page: 94" -->
<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Environmental Matters</B> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All
 of the centers presently owned by us (not including option interests in certain pre- development projects
 or any of the real estate managed but not included in our portfolio) have been subject to environmental
 assessments. We are not aware of any environmental liability relating to the centers or any other property,
 in which we have or had an interest (whether as an owner or operator) that we believe, would have a
 material adverse effect on our business, assets, or results of operations. No assurances can be given,
 however, that all environmental liabilities have been identified or that no prior owner, operator, or
 current occupant has created an environmental condition not known to us. Moreover, no assurances can
 be given that (1) future laws, ordinances, or regulations will not impose any material environmental
 liability or that (2) the current environmental condition of the centers will not be affected by tenants
 and occupants of the centers, by the condition of properties in the vicinity of the centers (such as
 the presence of underground storage tanks), or by third parties unrelated to us. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

 of employees by operational areas as of December 31, 2003: </FONT></P>

 on Form 10-K, Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q, and Current Reports on Form 8-K, as well as any amendments

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Item 2. PROPERTIES. </B></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Ownership</I> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
 following table sets forth certain information about each of the centers. The table includes only centers
 in operation at December 31, 2003. Excluded from this table is Northlake Mall which will open in 2005.
 Centers are owned in fee other than Beverly Center, Cherry Creek, International Plaza, MacArthur Center,
 and Sunvalley, which are held under ground leases expiring between 2049 and 2083. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain
 of the centers are partially owned through joint ventures. Generally, the Operating Partnership&#146;s joint
 venture partners have ongoing rights with regard to the disposition of the Operating Partnership&#146;s interest
 in the joint ventures, as well as the approval of certain major matters. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><I>Mortgage Debt</I> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
 following table sets forth certain information regarding the mortgages encumbering the centers as of
 December 31, 2003. All mortgage debt in the table below is nonrecourse to the Operating Partnership,
 except for debt encumbering Dolphin Mall, Stony Point Fashion Park, The Mall at Wellington Green, and
 The Shops at Willow Bend. The Operating Partnership has guaranteed the payment of all or a portion of
 the principal and interest on the mortgage debt of these centers. The Stony Point Fashion Park and Wellington
 Green loan agreements provide for the reduction of the amounts guaranteed as certain center performance
 and valuation criteria are met. (See &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and
 Results of Operations &#151; Liquidity and Capital Resources &#151; Covenants and Commitments&#148;). Assessment bonds
 totaling approximately $0.2 million, which are not included in the table, also encumber Sunvalley. A
 $2.3 million note secured by certain equipment of The Mall at Millenia is also excluded. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Flush Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Item 3. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS.</B> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Information
 required by this Item regarding proceedings terminated in the fourth quarter of 2003 is included in
 this report at Item 7 under the caption Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition
 and Results of Operations, Unsolicited Tender Offer. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Neither
 we, our subsidiaries, nor any of the joint ventures is presently involved in any material litigation,
 nor, to our knowledge, is any material litigation threatened against us, our subsidiaries, or any of
 the properties. Except for routine litigation involving present or former tenants (generally eviction
 or collection proceedings), substantially all litigation is covered by liability insurance. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Flush Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Item 4. SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY
 HOLDERS.</B> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On December
 19, 2003, we held our annual meeting of shareholders. The matters on which shareholders voted were:
 the election of three directors to serve a three year term, and the ratification of the Board&#146;s selection
 of Deloitte &amp; Touche LLP as our independent auditors for the year ended December 31, 2003. Graham
 T. Allison, Peter Karmanos, Jr., and William S. Taubman were re-elected at the meeting, and the six
 remaining incumbent directors, Robert S. Taubman, Lisa A. Payne, Allan J. Bloostein, Jerome A. Chazen,
 S. Parker Gilbert, and Myron E. Ullman, III, continued to hold office after the meeting. The shareholders
 ratified the selection of the independent auditors. The results of the voting are shown below: </FONT>
</P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>PART II </B></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Flush Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Item 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT&#146;S COMMON EQUITY AND
 RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS. </B></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
 common stock of Taubman Centers, Inc. is listed and traded on the New York Stock Exchange (Symbol: TCO).
 As of March 5, 2004, the 50,456,343 outstanding shares of Common Stock were held by 675 holders of record.
 The closing price per share of the Common Stock on the New York Stock Exchange on March 5 was $24.68.
 </FONT></P>

<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>In August 2000, we completed a transaction to acquire an additional interest in one of our Unconsolidated Joint Ventures; TRG became the 100% owner of Twelve Oaks Mall and the joint venture partner became the 100% owner of Lakeside. We recognized a gain on the transaction representing the excess of the fair value over the net book basis of our interest in Lakeside. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>


<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para (List) Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

<TD width="5%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>(2) </FONT></TD>
<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>In January 2002, we adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 144 &#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets.&#148; In accordance with this Statement, we have classified the results of Biltmore Fashion Park, which was sold in 2003, and La Cumbre Plaza and Paseo Nuevo, which were sold in 2002, as discontinued operations in all periods. Discontinued operations in 2003 and 2002 include gains on dispositions of interests in centers of $49.6 million and $12.3 million, respectively. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>


<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para (List) Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>

<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>In January 2001, we adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 133 &#147;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&#148; and its amendments and interpretations. We recognized a loss as a transition adjustment to mark our share of interest rate agreements to fair value as of January 1, 2001. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>


<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para (List) Hang Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<TABLE cellSpacing=0 cellPadding=0 width="100%" border=0>
<TR vAlign=top>

<TD width="95%"><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=1>Funds from Operations is defined and discussed in MD&amp;A &#150; Presentation of Operating Results. Net income and Funds from Operations include costs incurred in connection with the unsolicited tender offer, net of recoveries, of $24.8 million and $5.1 million in 2003 and 2002, respectively. Amounts for prior years have been restated to include items previously classified as extraordinary or unusual. </FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<H1 align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" color=#0000ff size=2>15 </FONT></H1>

<!-- MARKER PAGE="sheet: 101; page: 101" -->
<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Item 7. MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL
 CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS.</B> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF<BR><U>FINANCIAL
 CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS </U></FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
 following Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations contains
 various &#147;forward-looking statements&#148; within the meaning of Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933,
 as amended, and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended. These forward-looking
 statements represent our expectations or beliefs concerning future events, including the following:
 statements regarding future developments and joint ventures, rents and returns, statements regarding
 the continuation of trends, and any statements regarding the sufficiency of our cash balances and cash
 generated from operating and financing activities for our future liquidity and capital resource needs.
 We caution that although forward-looking statements reflect our good faith beliefs and best judgment
 based upon current information, these statements are qualified by important factors that could cause
 actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements, including those risks,
 uncertainties, and factors detailed from time to time in reports filed with the SEC, and in particular
 those set forth under the headings &#147;General Risks of the Company&#148; and &#147;Environmental Matters&#148; in our
 Annual Report on Form 10-K. The following discussion should be read in conjunction with the accompanying
 Consolidated Financial Statements of Taubman Centers, Inc. and the Notes thereto. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>General Background and Performance Measurement </B></FONT>
</P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Taubman
 Centers, Inc. (&#147;we&#148;, &#147;us&#148;, &#147;our&#148; or &#147;TCO&#148;) owns a managing general partner&#146;s interest in The Taubman
 Realty Group Limited Partnership (the Operating Partnership or TRG), through which we conduct all of
 our operations. The Operating Partnership owns, develops, acquires, and operates regional shopping centers
 nationally. The Consolidated Businesses consist of shopping centers that are controlled by ownership
 or contractual agreement, development projects for future regional shopping centers, and The Taubman
 Company LLC (the Manager). Shopping centers that are not controlled and that are owned through joint
 ventures with third parties (Unconsolidated Joint Ventures) are accounted for under the equity method.
 </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;References
 in this discussion to &#147;beneficial interest&#148; refer to our ownership or pro-rata share of the item being
 discussed. Also, the operations of the shopping centers are often best understood by measuring their
 performance as a whole, without regard to our ownership interest. Consequently, in addition to the discussion
 of the operations of the Consolidated Businesses, the operations of the Unconsolidated Joint Ventures
 are presented and discussed as a whole. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There
 are a number of items that affect the comparability of information used in measuring performance. During
 2003, we opened Stony Point Fashion Park (Results of Operations &#151; Recent Openings), acquired an interest
 in Waterside Shops at Pelican Bay, and sold our interest in Biltmore Fashion Park (Results of Operations
 &#151; Acquisitions and Dispositions). During 2002, we opened The Mall at Millenia (Results of Operations
 &#151; Recent Openings). Also during 2002, we acquired an interest in Sunvalley and sold our interests in
 La Cumbre Plaza and Paseo Nuevo (Results of Operations &#150; Acquisitions and Dispositions). We opened four
 new shopping centers during 2001, which are currently not at stabilization. Additional &#147;comparable center&#148;
 statistics that exclude Biltmore, La Cumbre Plaza, The Mall at Millenia, Paseo Nuevo, Stony Point, Sunvalley,
 Waterside Shops at Pelican Bay, and the centers that opened in 2001 are provided to present the performance
 of comparable centers in our continuing operations. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Overall Summary of Management's Discussion and Analysis
 of Financial Condition and Results of Operations</B> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 business is to lease space in our shopping centers. Generally these leases are long term (7 to 10 years).
 Therefore general economic trends most directly impact our tenants&#146; sales and consequently their ability
 to perform under their existing lease agreements and expand into new locations as well as our ability
 to find new tenants for our shopping centers. Tenant rents and expense recoveries represent over 90%
 of our total revenues. We recently have experienced decreases in occupancy, primarily due to unscheduled
 tenant closings. The impact on our income has been somewhat moderated by a significant increase in lease
 cancellation revenue and leasing to temporary in-line tenants. These trends are discussed under &#147;Current
 Operating Trends.&#148; The trend in tenant sales improved in 2003. Sales per square foot in 2003 continued
 to lead the industry, while mall tenant occupancy costs as a percentage of sales are within our historical
 norms. See &#147;Mall Tenant Sales and Center Revenues&#148; and &#147;Rental Rates and Occupancy.&#148; </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<H1 align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" color=#0000ff size=2>16 </FONT></H1>

<!-- MARKER PAGE="sheet: 102; page: 102" -->
<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
 rents we are able to achieve are similarly affected by economic trends and tenants&#146; expectations thereof,
 as described under &#147;Rental Rates and Occupancy&#148;. In 2003, the spread between rents of tenants opening
 and those closing was within historical norms. Mall tenant sales, occupancy levels and our resulting
 revenues are seasonal in nature. Refer to &#147;Seasonality&#148; for these relationships, as well as descriptions
 of revenues that historically are not as predictable. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 analysis of our financial results begins under &#147;Results of Operations&#148;. We have been active in developing
 and expanding our shopping center portfolio, and we describe the most recent center openings, including
 Stony Point Fashion Park and The Mall at Millenia under &#147;Recent Openings&#148;. Also, over the last two years,
 we acquired additional interests in six centers and disposed of interests in three, as discussed under
 &#147;Acquisitions and Dispositions&#148;. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We similarly
 have been very active in managing our balance sheet, completing a series of new financings or refinancings
 of existing debt, as well as a series of stock buybacks, issuances of partnership equity, and redemptions
 of partners&#146; interests in TRG, as outlined under &#147;Debt Transactions&#148; and &#147;Equity Transactions&#148;. We believe
 good balance sheet management &#151; both for debt and equity &#151; will continue to minimize exposure to interest
 rate risk and ensure adequate liquidity over the coming years. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the
 fall of 2002, we received an unsolicited proposal from Simon Property Group, which sought to acquire
 control of the company. A tender offer and litigation were commenced but ultimately ended in 2003 as
 described under &#147;Unsolicited Tender Offer&#148;. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have
 certain additional sources of income beyond our rental revenues and recoveries from tenants. We disclose
 the Operating Partnership&#146;s share of these sources of income under &#147;Other Income&#148;. Included in this
 income are lease cancellation income and gains on peripheral land sales , which in 2003 were at a historical
 high and close to a historical low, respectively. The timing of this income is difficult to predict.
 Other sources of income derived from our shopping centers, such as parking garage and sponsorship income,
 have been increasing. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We provide
 property management, leasing, development, and other administrative services to centers owned by General
 Motors pension trusts, other third parties, and certain Taubman affiliates. The General Motors pension
 trusts contracts are cancelable with 90 days notice. Certain annual overhead costs allocated to these
 contracts would not be eliminated if they were to be canceled or not renewed. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain
 significant transactions that occurred in 2004, including financings and an acquisition of an additional
 interest in Beverly Center, are discussed in &#147;Subsequent Events&#148;. The preparation of our financial statements
 requires management to make significant estimates when applying certain accounting policies. Background
 and discussion of these policies, including those related to the valuation of our shopping centers,
 capitalization of development costs, valuation of accounts receivable, and valuations for acquired property
 and intangibles, are contained under &#147;Application of Critical Accounting Policies&#148;. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With
 all the preceding information as background, we have then provided insight and explanations for variances
 in our financial results from 2001 through 2003 under &#147;Comparison of 2003 to 2002&#148; and &#147;Comparison of
 2002 to 2001". As information useful to understanding our results, we have described the presentation
 of our minority interest, the recent dispositions of interests in centers, and the reasons for our use
 of non-GAAP statistics such as EBITDA and Funds from Operations (FFO) under &#147;Presentation of Operating
 Results&#148;. Reconciliations from net income allocable to common shareowners to these statistics follow
 the annual comparisons. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 discussion of sources and uses of capital resources under &#147;Liquidity and Capital Resources&#148; begins with
 a brief overview of capital activities and transactions occurring in 2003. Analysis of specific operating,
 investing, and financing activities is then provided in more detail. Cash flows from rents and recoveries
 provide the resources for payments of interest and other operating expenses, leasing costs, and generally
 for required distributions and dividends. Recent positive operating cash flow generated by new center
 openings, increases in rents, and other positive events offset the cash used in connection with the
 unsolicited tender offer. Similarly, significant capital outflows continue in connection with the construction
 of new centers and acquisitions, financed through sales of centers, debt, and certain equity issuances.
 </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<H1 align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" color=#0000ff size=2>17 </FONT></H1>

<!-- MARKER PAGE="sheet: 103; page: 103" -->
<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Funding
 for new developments, acquisitions, and other capital spending typically is provided by new borrowings.
 As new developments reach their expected stabilized occupancy, we may be able to refinance the assets
 for more than the original financings, providing additional resources for growth. Specific analysis
 of our fixed and floating rates and periods of interest rate risk exposure is provided under &#147;Beneficial
 Interest in Debt&#148;. Completing our analysis of our exposure to rates are the effects of changes in interest
 rates on our cash flows and fair values of debt contained under &#147;Sensitivity Analysis&#148;. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In conducting
 our business, we enter into various contractual obligations, including those for debt, capital leases
 for property improvements, operating leases for office space and land, purchase obligations, and other
 long-term commitments. Detail of these obligations, including expected settlement periods, is contained
 under &#147;Contractual Obligations&#148;. Property-level debt represents the largest single class of obligations,
 in both total amount and near-term maturity/expected settlement. Described under &#147;Loan Commitments and
 Guarantees&#148; and &#147;Cash Tender Agreement&#148; are our significant guarantees and commitments. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Development,
 renovation, and expansion of new and existing malls continues to be a significant use of our capital,
 as described in &#147;Capital Spending&#148; and &#147;Planned Capital Spending&#148;. Recent spending includes that related
 to the recently opened Stony Point Fashion Park and The Mall at Millenia, and the currently under construction
 Northlake Mall. A use of future capital may be for our planned Oyster Bay project in Syosset, New York.
 We hope to resolve entitlement issues and receive the necessary approvals to begin construction in late
 2004 for a planned 2006 opening of this project. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Dividends
 are also significant uses of our capital resources. Tax status of our dividends and the factors considered
 when determining the amount of our dividends, including requirements arising because of our status as
 a REIT, are described under &#147;Dividends&#148;. We again increased our quarterly dividend in the fourth quarter
 of 2003. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Current Operating Trends</B> </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since
 2001 the regional shopping center industry has been affected by the softness in the national economy.
 Economic and geopolitical pressures that affect consumer confidence, job growth, energy costs, and income
 gains can affect retail sales growth and impact our ability to lease vacancies and negotiate rents at
 advantageous rates. The impact of a soft economy on our current results of operations can be moderated
 by lease cancellation income, which tends to increase in down-cycles of the economy. During 2003, we
 recognized our approximately $11.7 million share of lease cancellation revenue, which exceeded historical
 averages; this level of lease cancellation income is not indicative of future periods (see Results of
 Operations &#151; Other Income). </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
 sales statistics have shown improvement over the last nine months of 2003 (see Mall Tenant Sales and
 Center Revenues). Sales directly impact the amount of percentage rents certain tenants and anchors pay.
 The effects of increases or declines in sales on our operations are moderated by the relatively minor
 share of total rents (approximately two percent) percentage rents represent. However, a sustained trend
 in sales does impact, either negatively or positively, our ability to lease vacancies and negotiate
 rents at advantageous rates. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2003,
 we experienced a decrease in occupancy from 2002 (see Rental Rates and Occupancy). Increased income
 from temporary in-line tenants, which has become an integral part of our business, partially offsets
 the impact of lower occupancy in the portfolio. Temporary tenants, defined as those with lease terms
 less than 12 months, are not included in occupancy or leased space statistics. As of December 31, 2003,
 approximately 3.7% of space was occupied by temporary tenants. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Left-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<P align=left><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2><B>Mall Tenant Sales and Center Revenues</B> </FONT>
</P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Over
 the long term, the level of mall tenant sales is the single most important determinant of revenues of
 the shopping centers because mall tenants provide approximately 90% of these revenues and because mall
 tenant sales determine the amount of rent, percentage rent, and recoverable expenses (together, total
 occupancy costs) that mall tenants can afford to pay. However, levels of mall tenant sales can be considerably
 more volatile in the short run than total occupancy costs. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->

<P><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" size=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe
 that the ability of tenants to pay occupancy costs and earn profits over long periods of time increases
 as sales per square foot increase, whether through inflation or real growth in customer spending. Because
 most mall tenants have certain fixed expenses, the occupancy costs that they can afford to pay and still
 be profitable are a higher percentage of sales at higher sales per square foot. </FONT></P>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Head Minor Center Bold-Arial" FSL="Workstation" -->
<H1 align=center><FONT face="Arial, Helvetica, Sans-Serif" color=#0000ff size=2>18 </FONT></H1>

<!-- MARKER PAGE="sheet: 104; page: 104" -->
<HR color=gray noShade SIZE=5>

<!-- MARKER FORMAT-SHEET="Para Indent Lv 0-Arial" FSL="Default" -->
